title: Petropavlovsk ‘will pay debts’
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Sun, Jul 5, 2015, 04:06 BST - UK Markets closed Petropavlovsk ‘will pay debts’ 7.42 -0.06 
The London-listed company narrowly avoided collapse earlier this year after shareholders and creditors approved an emergency rights issue and financial restructuring 
PETER Hambro, founder of troubled Anglo-Russian gold miner Petropavlovsk (LSE: POG.L - news ) , has vowed to rebuild the firm and pay off its debts. 
The London-listed company narrowly avoided collapse earlier this year after shareholders and creditors approved an emergency rights issue and financial restructuring. 
Petropavlovsk had seen its shares plummet by 50pc during the year after it loaded up on debt to fund new mine expansions. 
In an interview with The Sunday Telegraph, Mr Hambro said: “The base case is that we pay off the debt, but there is more we can do. Paying off the debt restores the enterprise value to the shareholders and that is the number one thing we want to do.” 
Mr Hambro said the company may revive its plan to process refractory ore by completing building of processing facilities, which its financial troubles halted. It could also invest in digging deeper into existing mines to access high-quality ore. 
Petropavlovsk may invest up to $50m into work that will allow it to mine existing pits laterally from the side to boost productivity. 
The company is expected to produce 680,000 ounces of gold this year and sustain production at above 600,000 ounces for the next five years. 
Mining companies such as Petropavlovsk were caught out by the gold price crash from a record above $1,930 per ounce a few years ago to around $1,200 now. 
Mr Hambro said it remains profitable with a margin of around $500 per ounce, which should generate $300m of revenue this year
